docs.abstract: Conservatives are lining up not to denounce judicial activism, but to embrace it.
docs.snippet: Conservatives are lining up not to denounce judicial activism, but to embrace it.

docs.lead_paragraph: Remember judicial activism? Of course you do. Not so long ago, Republicans lined up to denounce President Obama's two Supreme Court nominees as judicial activists before the ink was dry on their nomination papers. Writing in The Wall Street Journal right after Sonia Sotomayor's nomination in May 2009, Karl Rove advised fellow Republicans that although Judge Sotomayor would almost certainly be confirmed, Republicans should nonetheless seek to score points by "making a clear case against the judicial activism she represents." The next year, Sen. Orrin Hatch of Utah, undeterred by the fact that Elena Kagan, never having been a judge, was hard to describe plausibly as a judicial activist, explained his vote against her confirmation by saying that "Ms. Kagan's record shows that she supports an activist judicial philosophy."
docs.abstract: Conservatives are lining up not to denounce judicial activism, but to embrace it.
docs.snippet: Conservatives are lining up not to denounce judicial activism, but to embrace it.

headline.print_headline: Gloom Grips Consumers; It May Be Home Prices

docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration was wise to suspend part of its health reform geared toward long-term care, but the problem isn’t going away.

headline.seo: The Class Program Didn’t Add Up

docs.abstract: Editorial holds that the Obama administration was wise to suspend part of its health reform geared toward long-term care, because the program was not financially sustainable; asserts, however, that the problem of affordable long-term care is not going away and will have to be tackled eventually.
